description: From Middle English warnen, warnien (“to warn; admonish”), from Old English warnian (“to take heed; warn”), from Proto-Germanic *warnōną (“to warn; take heed”), from Proto-Indo-European *wer- (“to be aware; give heed”). Cognate with Dutch waarnen (obsolete), German Low German warnen, German warnen, Swedish varna, Icelandic varna.

verbs.description: warn (third-person singular simple present warns, present participle warning, simple past and past participle warned)

definitionGroups.group: (transitive) To make (someone) aware of (something impending); especially:

entries.meaning: (transitive) To make (someone) aware of impending danger, evil, etc. [from 11th c.]
examples: We waved a flag to warn the oncoming traffic about the accident.
I phoned to warn him of the road closure.

entries.meaning: (transitive) To notify or inform (someone, about something). [from at least the 13th c.]
examples: I warned him he'd be getting a huge box of birthday presents from me.

entries.meaning: (transitive) To summon (someone) to or inform of a formal meeting or duty.
examples: The sheriff warned her to appear in court.

entries.meaning: (transitive, intransitive, of a clock, possibly obsolete) To make a sound (e.g. clicking or whirring) indicating that it is about to strike or chime (an hour).
examples: Hark! the clock is warning ten;

entries.meaning: (transitive) To caution or admonish (someone) against unwise or unacceptable behaviour. [from 11th c.]
examples: He was warned against crossing the railway tracks at night.
Don't let me catch you running in the corridor again, I warn you.

entries.meaning: (chiefly with "off", "away", and similar words) To advise or order to go or stay away.
examples: A sign warns trespassers off/away from the site.
She is his deepest innocence in spaces of bough and hay before wishes were given a different name to warn that they might not come true [...].
